message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of PTSD, such as re-experiencing the traumatic event, avoidance, and hypervigilance. The patient’s symptoms have lasted longer than 1 month, ruling out acute stress disorder, and are not limited to the normal grieving process, ruling out adjustment disorder. While the patient may also have depressive symptoms, they are secondary to the PTSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient is experiencing post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) as she has nightmares about the traumatic event, avoids reminders of the trauma, and is experiencing emotional numbness. Acute stress disorder typically lasts for a shorter duration and is characterized by dissociative symptoms. Major depressive disorder involves persistent feelings of sadness, guilt, and hopelessness. Adjustment disorder involves the development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to a stressor but does not meet the diagnostic criteria for another disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms match those of post-traumatic stress disorder, including intense feelings of guilt and avoidance behavior. The symptoms have persisted for more than 1 month, ruling out acute stress disorder. Although the patient may also have symptoms of major depressive disorder, the key feature in this case is the trauma-related symptoms, making PTSD the most likely diagnosis over adjustment disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including nightmares, re-experiencing the accident, avoidance behavior, and withdrawal suggest the most likely diagnosis is post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Acute stress disorder is a similar but shorter-lived condition, and major depressive disorder and adjustment disorder do not fully capture the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of vivid nightmares, re-experiencing the event, avoidance behavior, and withdrawal suggest that the patient is experiencing Post-traumatic stress disorder. Acute stress disorder and adjustment disorder are shorter-lasting and less severe. Major depressive disorder usually does not involve re-experiencing traumatic events.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of re-experiencing the traumatic event, avoidance behavior, and feelings of guilt and withdrawal suggest post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Acute stress disorder only lasts for up to one month after the traumatic event, while major depressive disorder and adjustment disorder do not have the symptoms of re-experiencing and avoidance behavior as seen in PTSD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), as she is experiencing re-experiencing symptoms, avoidance behaviors, and changes in cognition and mood. PTSD occurs after a traumatic event and can persist for months or even years.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of vivid nightmares, re-experiencing, avoidance, and withdrawal suggest a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder. Acute stress disorder only lasts for up to 4 weeks after the traumatic event, while major depressive disorder and adjustment disorder do not fit the presentation well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including vivid nightmares and re-experiencing the traumatic event, suggest a diagnosis of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The patient’s avoidance of certain situations is also indicative of PTSD. The time frame of the symptoms is longer than acute stress disorder, which resolves within a month, and not consistent with adjustment disorder. Major depressive disorder is a possibility but is not the most likely diagnosis given the focus on the traumatic event and PTSD symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms that have lasted for more than a month and include re-experiencing the traumatic event, avoiding stimuli related to the event, and hyperarousal, suggesting a diagnosis of Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Acute stress disorder is similar to PTSD but lasts less than one month, while major depressive disorder and adjustment disorder do not include the specific symptoms related to PTSD.
